page.title: 12THE RIVER BURE
page.content: The River Bure is by far the most important geographical feature in this D_BLOCK. It winds its way for about six kilometres over the area. Its flow is checked by the mill at Buxton. At one time there used to be a lock at this point but this has long since disappeared. It is shallow and slow moving and is on average about 5m wide. It flows into the North Sea at Great Yarmouth after passing through The Broads of which it is the main river. It is not navigable at this point only by canoes and light craft. All the usual water and waterside plants grow here, there being no special ones. The river contains stocks of bream, roach, dace, perch, gudgeon and pike. Birds which are seen regularly on the river are mute swans, Canada geese, moorhens, mallard and herons.
